speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me when your fever started and how high it has been?

speaker: Patient
text: It started about two days ago, and it has been around 101 to 102 degrees Fahrenheit. I've been feeling pretty warm and uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any chills, night sweats, or changes in your vaginal discharge since giving birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any chills or night sweats, but I have noticed some changes in my vaginal discharge. It seems a bit different than what I expected after giving birth.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any abdominal pain or tenderness, and if so, can you describe the severity and location?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I have some uterine tenderness, especially when I touch my abdomen. It feels more pronounced in the lower part of my belly, and it's uncomfortable but not excruciating.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any foul-smelling discharge or any unusual odor coming from your vaginal area?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any foul smell, but the discharge does seem different in color and consistency compared to what I expected. It's a bit concerning to me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any difficulty urinating or any pain while urinating since giving birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any pain while urinating, but I do feel like I need to go more frequently than usual. It's been a bit bothersome.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent procedures or interventions, such as a cesarean section or any manual removal of the placenta?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any recent procedures or interventions; my delivery was vaginal and uncomplicated. Everything seemed normal at the time.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any nausea, vomiting, or changes in your appetite since giving birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any nausea or vomiting, but my appetite has decreased a bit. I just don't feel as hungry as I usually do.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any swelling in your legs or any signs of redness or warmth in your lower extremities?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any swelling in my legs, and there doesn't seem to be any redness or warmth in my lower extremities. They feel normal to me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent blood tests or cultures done since your fever started?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I haven't had any blood tests or cultures done since my fever started. I haven't been to the doctor for that yet.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any breast tenderness or issues with breastfeeding, such as pain or difficulty?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any breast tenderness, and breastfeeding has been going well for the most part. There’s been some discomfort, but nothing too severe.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your energy levels or overall fatigue since giving birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I've definitely been feeling more fatigued than usual. I find myself needing to rest more often, and I just don't have the same energy I used to.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent infections or illnesses prior to giving birth, or any history of infections during your pregnancy?

speaker: Patient
text: I didn't have any infections or illnesses prior to giving birth, and my pregnancy was uncomplicated with no history of infections. Everything seemed fine until after delivery.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any pain or discomfort in your breasts, or any signs of mastitis, such as redness or swelling?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't experienced any pain or discomfort in my breasts, and there are no signs of redness or swelling. Everything seems normal in that area.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you had any recent imaging studies, such as an ultrasound of your abdomen or pelvis, to check for any abnormalities?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any recent imaging studies done, like an ultrasound. I haven't felt the need for it yet, but I'm open to it if you think it's necessary.

speaker: Doctor
text: Would you be willing to undergo an ultrasound of your abdomen and pelvis to check for any potential abnormalities, such as retained products of conception or other issues?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I would be willing to undergo an ultrasound. I just want to make sure everything is okay after giving birth.

speaker: Doctor
text: REQUEST TEST: Abdominal_and_Pelvic_Ultrasound. While we wait for the ultrasound results, can you tell me if you've had any fever spikes or if the fever has been consistent since it started?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: 102°F (38.9°C) - consistent fever since it started.

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any specific triggers or activities that seem to worsen your abdominal tenderness or fever?

speaker: Patient
text: I've noticed that the tenderness seems to worsen when I try to engage in any physical activity or even when I’m just moving around the house. It makes me feel more uncomfortable and the fever seems to spike a bit afterward.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given your symptoms and the ultrasound results, I want to ask if you've experienced any unusual bleeding or clots since giving birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't noticed any unusual bleeding or large clots since giving birth. My bleeding seems to be within the normal range, but I do feel a bit uneasy about everything.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on your symptoms and the ultrasound results, I want to ask if you have experienced any pain or discomfort in your lower back or if you have had any chills or fever spikes during the night?

speaker: Patient
text: I haven't had any pain or discomfort in my lower back, but I have experienced some fever spikes during the night. It makes it hard to sleep comfortably.

speaker: Doctor
text: DIAGNOSIS READY: Postpartum endometritis.
